title: Easily Reset an Anki Deck in 5 Quick Steps

steps.title: If you changed certain cards or flipped through too quickly to retain them, you can reset part of your deck.
steps.content: If you changed certain cards or flipped through too quickly to retain them, you can reset part of your deck. This is useful when you've made changes to cards or otherwise want to make unfamiliar cards new again. Just make sure not to reset the cards you haven't made changes to or have already learned .

steps.title: If you're behind in your review, it's not a good idea to reset your Anki deck.
steps.content: If you're behind in your review, it's not a good idea to reset your Anki deck. Even if you have a large backlog of cards to review, resetting your deck is not recommended and can even interfere with your ability to learn newer and more difficult material. After all, you'll have to start over with the cards you've already learned, which means you'll see those cards just as often as the ones you still need to learn. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Open the Anki desktop or browser app.
steps.content: Open the Anki desktop or browser app. If you're using Anki on a computer or in your web browser, you can easily reset your progress in a deck by "forgetting" the cards.

steps.title: Click Browse.
steps.content: Click Browse . You'll see this at the top of the window.

steps.title: Select a deck.
steps.content: Select a deck. If you have multiple decks, you can choose a deck (such as a Zanki deck) from your deck list in the left panel.

steps.title: Select all of the cards you want to forget.
steps.content: Select all of the cards you want to forget. You can click and drag to highlight all the cards, or hold down the Ctrl key (PC) or Command key (Mac) to select multiple cards at once. You can quickly select all cards by pressing Ctrl + A (PC) or Command + A (Mac).

steps.title: Click Cards menu and select Forget.
steps.content: Click Cards menu and select Forget . This instantly changes the state of the selected cards back to New. [2] X Research source You can also just right-click the selected cards and choose Forget , or press Ctrl + Alt + N . While your history will still show any previous reviews you've completed, that won't influence the forgotten cards, which are now new again.

steps.title: Select Easy on the cards you already know.
steps.content: Select Easy on the cards you already know. If you have too many cards in your review deck and want to bring the difficult ones to the front of the queue, mark the cards you already know as Easy to convert the card to a Review card. [3] X Research source The card will then be shown 4 days later, and then at an increasing interval as you continue to study with the deck. In the meantime, you can catch up on the cards you still need to review.

steps.title: Move new cards to the end of the deck.
steps.content: Move new cards to the end of the deck. If you're getting too much new information before learning older cards, you can go to Tools > Preferences (Windows/Linux) or Anki > Preferences (Mac) and set the second drop-down box to after all reviews .

steps.title: Change your daily review limit.
steps.content: Change your daily review limit. If it's been hard to recover from a backlog of cards, you can set up a daily review limit to study a set of overdue cards until you've caught up. [4] X Research source The default is 200 per day, but you can click the Reviews tab and select a lower value for "Maximum reviews/day. You can also try the Anki Limit New extension, which limits the number of new cards shown based on your current workload. You can get it from https://github.com/ig3/anki-limitnew . [5] X Research source
